content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements if not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 allow group health plans to negotiate separate reimbursement rates and manage benefits through mechanisms like pre-admission screening. It does not require specific mental health benefits or prevent plans from providing them. The provisions of section 2705 apply to individual market health insurance coverage in the same way as group health plan coverage. Effective dates for group health plans begin on or after July 1, 1999, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment. The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c) do not apply to plan years starting before the later of the termination of collective bargaining agreements or July 1, 1999. Plan amendments made to comply with the requirements of the Act do not count as terminating collective bargaining agreements. The amendment made by subsection (d) applies to individual health insurance coverage in the market from July 1, 1999. PARITY IN THE APPLICATION OF LIMITS TO SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND CHEMICAL DEPENDENCY BENEFITS. Amends Employee Retirement Income Security Act to apply limits to substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits in the same manner as mental health benefits. Sec. 713 amends the Public Health Service Act to ensure parity in limits for substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits. It applies to group health plans and health insurance issuers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is also amended to include this provision. Sec. 9813 ensures parity in limits for substance abuse and chemical dependency benefits under group health plans and individual health insurance coverage.
